title: Opening up the Museum: Nina Simon @ TEDxSantaCruz

json.text: Translator: Kaoru Suzuki Reviewer: Denise RQ
Thank you.
I want to be real up-front about the fact that I am an activist about this stuff.
I want to share with you today the passion of my professional work
which is about opening up museums,
turning them into places that are not just places where people come to visit
but where you can actively participate, where you can connect with culture,
and hopefully, through these experiences connect more deeply with each other.
The problem is that for most people, museums are not seen as open spaces.
Museums are seen as elite institutions.
New York.
(Laughter)
They're seen as elite institutions
that serve an increasingly small and limited subset of our population.
So when most people go looking for a cultural experience,
they don't go to a museum.
We live in an incredibly fertile creative time.
Look at what Luke's doing, and Ally,
all of the wonderful artists and cultural enthusiasts in our community.
You don't have to be a professional to be excited about culture today.
People are getting together in bars to knit.
People are renting space and starting businesses
so they can do science experiments together.
The research on this is very clear:
throughout our country, people are more culturally engaged than ever,
but they are choosing to have those experiences
outside of traditional cultural institutions.
That means you're way more likely today to pick up a paint brush
than you're to go to an art museum.
Instead of going to a history museum,
people are doing their own genealogical research.
As a museum director, I look at this, and I say,
"We have to get in on this game! These are people who care about culture.
They're passionate about the things that we protect,
and yet, weren't staying at arm's length."
What is that about?
When I talk with museum professionals about this,
I hear some interest, but I also hear some real concern.
This is a quote from a friend of mine who works for the Smithsonian.
She said, "I know a lot of people who work in art museums
who would recoil in horror at the idea of being inundated by Sunday painters."
I'm sorry, but if people who paint on Sundays
aren't the core audience for an art museum, I don't know who is.
(Applause)
Here in Santa Cruz at our museum, the Santa Cruz Museum of Art & History,
we've decided we're going to open up to participatory culture.
We are going to embrace it.
So, yes, we invite people to paint with us on Sundays.
We encourage them to share their own creative skills with each other,
and you know what?
Sometimes, that involves tools that are a lot more extreme than paint brushes.
(Laughter)
What I want to share with you today are just two of the ways
that we are opening up our museum,
and how it's changing
both our organization and hopefully, our community.
The first side of this is about active participation.
We don't just invite you in to come visit.
We expect every person who walks in our museum
to contribute something to make our museum better.
That means from the instant you walk in the door,
you will be asked to give us a suggestion of how we can improve the museum.
We've invited visitors to write poems about objects in our history gallery.
And now, if you come in on the first floor,
you can even bottle up a memory
and put it on display for other visitors to see.
Over the last year, thousands of visitors have contributed content to our museum
and it's beautiful, it's powerful, and it's meaningful
to other people who walk in the door.
But I think we all know
that we've had experiences with participatory public comment
that were not so meaningful.
In museums, you can see comment books like this
full of repetitive boring information.
"Sam was here," "Jasmin was here."
Thank you very much.
I think we're all really familiar with this kind of experience online.
I don't think any of the people
who made these YouTube comments are dumb people.
What I see here is a lack of a designed opportunity
to really invite them to give something meaningful to this situation.
I believe that everyone of us in this room
has something really powerful and creative to add.
I believe that everyone of us has a story to share,
that frankly, everyone of you probably
has something amazing to share from this stage today.
But I also know that everyone of us can be banal.
We can all be idiots sometimes.
And to me, as somebody who works on inviting participation,
the difference is in how we design the invitation to participate.
Good design can elevate us to share our the best selves
in a way that lousy design cannot.
Let me give you an example.
This is from an exhibition I worked on in Seattle a few years ago.
This exhibition was about advice.
These were just two ways in the exhibition
that you could give and get advice.
On the left, people could put up a question with a post-it,
and then, you could give suggestions.
People were very well-meaning and trying to help each other out here.
On the right, they had constructed a fake bathroom door.
You can see that mostly, what people did was scribble nonsense
or write, "For a good time, call Johnny."
It's not like when you came in the door to this exhibit,
we sent the well-meaning people to the post-its and the fools to the door.
The same people did both of these activities.
And the reason they interacted differently
was because of the design and the tools that were given to them.
Here is an even geekier example.
This is from the L.A. County Museum of Art.
They did this project a couple years ago
where they asked people a question about art.
They gave some visitors white cards and golf pencils
and gave some visitors these hexagonal, blue cards and big pencils.
And what they found was that people wrote better answers on the blue cards
than they did on the white.
Does this mean that blue is a magical color for participation?
No.
What it means is if you give somebody a special tool,
you make them feel valued,
you show them that you actually care about what they going to do
and it transforms with they do in return.
And so in our museum, we think really hard
about how to design those invitations to participate
in ways that encourage people to feel valued
and to feel like they better give something good back.
So when we asked people for their stories of relationship breakups,
we had them post them on this kind of wall.
When we invited them to share their favorite memories of coffee,
we gave them coffee beans to vote with
so that they could smell and feel that experience of coffee.
And again, when we wanted to ask people to share love letters,
we gave them a typewriter to work with,
an unfamiliar tool that caused them
to slow down and to share something different.
And right now, we're doing this memory jar installation
where we're giving people mason jars and craft materials,
and we're saying, "Think of a memory that's important to you,
use some craft materials to create a representation of it
and bottle it up for somebody else to see."
We've had over 300 people contribute jars in the last month.
And here is just one that I took a picture of last week.
It says, "I remember when you were alive,
before Iraq and open pit burns which gave you cancer.
I remember when we learned that you died in Iraq in our arms at home,
I miss you, I miss you."
I don't think this visitor, Mark, walked into the museum
expecting that he was going to share this story.
But this activity and the designed experience brought it out of him
and made him able to contribute something really powerful to our museum
and to the other visitors who walk in the door.
This kind of participation isn't just changing the content of the museum,
it's changing the way that visitors see themselves as creative agents.
We've had a lot of positive response to what we've been doing over the last year,
but one of my favorite quotes came from a teenager who said,
"We've been to famous art museums all over Europe,
but this is the first exhibit that makes me want to do art."
I looked at that, and I'm thrilled
not just because we turn somebody onto culture in a different way
but because this is somebody for whom the museum has become relevant.
This is somebody who is going to get more involved.
And over the last year, we've seen this happen again and again.
Just with one year of participation,
we've totally changed what's happening in our museum.
So, from last year to this year, our attendance has more than doubled,
our busiest day has more than tripped,
and we went from tenuous, financial position,
one so bad that you can't even see how much cash we had
at the bottom of that chart
(Laughter)
to a stable place that we can grow on.
By doing this kind of participatory stuff,
we are not just making the museum exciting,
we are making it sustainable for the future.
You might look at all this and wonder, "But what about the objects?"
Aren't museums fundamentally about artifacts?
And yes, we still have stuff at our museum.
The next side of this I want to talk about is how we are transforming our artifacts,
starting to look at them as opportunities
to mediate conversations between strangers.
To you an example, let's go outside the museum.
How many people here own a dog? OK. Great.
So you've all had this experience:
you're out walking your dog in public and a stranger comes up and talks to you.
They're not really talking directly to you;
they're talking through the dog to you.
The dog has become this safe social object
that mediates an encounter that otherwise wouldn't happen.
As a museum designer, I am really curious about this:
how could we make museum artifacts more like dogs?
(Laughter)
I'm serious.
How could we make them opportunities for conversations
that otherwise wouldn't happen?
Because the kinds of social experiences that people can have around museum objects
are bigger than the ones we have around our dogs.
When you're walking down the street,
you don't start having a conversation with a stranger
about what it's like to be in the military
like these people are as they're looking at art work.
When you're in the mall, you don't have a conversation about racial inequity
as these teenagers are as they look at stacks of money
representing income disparity between whites and blacks in the U.S.
Museum artifacts have the power to expose the big conversations
we have to be having about where we have been,
where we are now, and where we going to go.
So again, at our museum, we think really carefully
about how to bring to life the conversations
that can happen around these objects;
whether that's through a craft activity
that gets people deeply involved with the work
or an activity that invites them to select which objects belong in the museum
and which ones aren't relevant to our community.
Some museums don't even give you a comfortable opportunity
to sit down and talk about the objects on display.
We're really serious about this, so we even do things like design games
that invite people to engage more with the work.
And yes, all of these activities help people connect with the artifacts
and learn more about them.
But more importantly, to me, they help them connect with people
who are not like them and learn more about each other
because we all know how a powerful social object
can bridge a gap that otherwise we won't cross.
And that leads me to my last point which is that when do we this work,
when we invite people to participate,
when we see objects as loci of conversation,
we can transform museums from things that are nice to have
that things that are really necessary to move our communities forward.
It isn't just happening here in Santa Cruz,
it's happening all over the world, in Toronto at the Ontario Science Center
where they are inviting visitors to invent solutions to global problems.
It's happening in Minneapolis at the Institute of Art
where every ten years, they have an exhibit where they say,
"Anybody and everybody in the community can bring in a small artwork,
and we will hang it on the wall of a world class museum."
It's happening at the Brooklyn Museum of Art,
where we're using technology to experiment with new ways
for people to engage with artifacts and with each other.
Again, when I look at any of these examples
what I'm looking at are the people.
So when people at my museum are doing a craft activity together,
I don't just see people who are cutting up magazines,
I see people who come from different walks of life,
who've been brought together through a cultural experience.
In Santa Cruz, perhaps one of the most powerful experiences
we're having with that is happening outside the museum
at a historic site called Evergreen Cemetery.
About a year ago, the museum teamed up with the homeless service center,
and every Monday, museum volunteers and homeless volunteers come together
to restore this important, historic site for Santa Cruz.
And yes, it's incredible that they are beautifying it, and making it safe,
they are literally uncovering history
as they reveal gravestones of Santa Cruz's founders.
Everybody who comes out and works at Evergreen
has a powerful experience with history.
But more importantly, everybody who comes out to Evergreen
has a powerful experience with somebody who is not like them,
somebody who they might be fearful of in another situation.
And it's this kind of social bridging that culture can do
and can do so powerfully and so importantly for us today.
I want to leave you with just one last story of that kind,
a really special thing for me that happened at the museum.
A couple of months ago, we had this space set up
where people could make collages in the museum.
I walked through, and I saw this pretty typical museum scene.
In the background,
you have four young adults, Chicanos, who are making collages,
and in the foreground, you have a separate group,
one of our staff member, Stacey, who is meeting with an artists named Kyle,
and there is his baby just looking cute.
So two separate groups doing their thing in a museum.
But the next time I walked through,
I realized that, "Oh my gosh! These girls have gotten up,
and the baby and the collages, two great social objects,
have mediated a conversation between completely strangers
about making art, about being a parent, about making a child.
And then, the thing that happened next--
and I wish I had a picture of this--
the next time I walked through, Kyle has handed his baby to these girls,
and they are sitting and making collages,
and he is continuing his conversation with Stacy.
(Applause)
I know! I thought to myself,
"My god, if our museum can be the kind of place
where somebody will willingly give their baby to a stranger"
(Laugher)
then we are doing a lot to overcome fear and divisiveness in our community.
We live in a really divided world,
politically, economically, culturally.
I feel that we desperately need places that allow us
to have positive interactions with people who are not like us.
The ultimate measure of what we're doing right now at the Museum of Art &History
is not about the experiences that happen inside the museum.
It's about how those experiences transform
the ones that people have when they go outside.
I dream of a time when all of you can come participate in our museum,
can connect with culture, and can walk out
and have a better connection with somebody else on the street.
I dream of a time when you will walk down the street,
and you will look around, and you'll say,
"Gosh, this is our community."
You look at a stranger who is walking towards you,
and you won't think, "I'm going to ignore that person,"
or, "Well, I should turn away and go the other way.
Instead, you'll get excited because you'll say,
"I'll collaborate with this person. I want to get to know that person."
You may not hand them your baby, there on the street
(Laughter)
but don't worry.
You can come to our museum and do that.
Thank you.
(Applause)
